For instance, in Table 2, the reduction in fertility during the years immediately before 1976 may be inferred from CWR1. Interestingly, CWR2 which implies the fertility situation during the 5–9 years before the census does not show a declining trend in 1976 or 1991. 7 According to figures of the Statistical Center of Iran, the crude marriage rate rose from 5 per thousand in the immediate years before the Revolution to more than 8 per thousand in the years immediately after the Revolution (see SCI's annual Statistical Yearbook, various years Statistical Center of Iran (various years) Statistical Yearbook of Iran Tehran Statistical Center of Iran [Google Scholar].) There are indications that in the early 1980's, that is, the first few years after the revolution, fertility increased rapidly and reached a peak, after which point it decreased slightly up to 1988. 8 During the war, basic needs were rationed on the basis of the number of members in each family without any qualifications. This system of rationing allowed more shares and more coupons for larger families. A newly born child was not in need of such rationed goods as meat, rice, sugar, cooking oil until the end of the breast-feeding period (which, very often, takes as long as two years), yet the child began receiving coupons right after his or her birth. Thus, by having more children, families could get more coupons. Selling coupons to opportunists became a way of making money for poor families. 9 Due to the huge influx of refugees from Afghanistan and Iraq between 1976 and 1986, the average annual rate of inter-census population growth was 3.97 percent, of which 3.2 percent represented natural increase and 0.8 percent the migration of refugees. 10 Had it not been for the post-revolutionary pro-natalist atmosphere, presumably, the fertility decline probably would have continued during the period 1978–88. Therefore, although actions on the moderation of population growth rate were reinforced after 1988, the huge reduction in fertility during the 1990s should not be attributed totally to the programs conducted in that particular decade. What occurred was a resumption of the fertility trend that had been reversed for a decade as a result of the Islamic Revolution. Hence, some credit should be given to previous actions (before 1988) for the remarkable decline in fertility during the 1990s. 11 ESCAP, ‘I.R. of Iran's Report,’ ESCAP 1997 I.R.
